body.p:
Rev S. Morais
My valued friend!

Your postal card reached me to day,
and as the matter at time required some more expla-
nation than could be embodied in a telegram very well.
I thought better to write you in detail relative to your
enquiry. I enclose you a copy of the present constitu-
tion which we are working under, and will also give
you the amendment thereto which the committee of the
Board of Delegates have required of us to embody in the
constitution as a sine qui non for a basis of emalgation[sic?],
now in reply to your card, you are perfectly correct
as to what you understood from me when in Philadel-
phia, our congregations render an account for so ma-
ny members, renters of seats who have no voice in the
congregation no account is taken of them, when a congre
gation join the union, they report their number of mem-
bers and we do not go back of that return, if the
congregation Beth-El-Emeth write with us, whatever num-
ber of members they report as contributing members
to that congregation, it is supposed to be correct "we do
not go back of the returns," if the "Mickvah Israel Cong-
regation resolve to come into the union, the are ex-
pected to report to many contributing members, it is taken

for granted that they have rendered a correct report,
Dr Lilienthal's congregation for example, has say,
180 duly elected members, and say 40 or 50 or more
seat renters or holders as they may be properly
termed, who have no voice in the congregation at all,
have no other interest than to occupy a seat,
we would report 180 contributing members, using the
phraseology of the constitution; but, if the constitution
is amended in accordance with the wish of
the congregations, or the committee who represent
the Board of Delegates, we would be obliged to
report 220 or 230 or more contributing members and
seat holders; this amendment was proposed to meet
the emergency of the Eastern Congregations, that
they might be enabled to raise their minimum
of 2000 members; as they proposed to do, if we
make the various amendments they have proposed,
of which I send you a marked copy, of the pro-
ceedings of last council: congregations that now
join the union unconditionally as all have done
heretofore, come in under the provisions of the pres-
ent constitution, and they must construe its meaning
according to their capacity, of understanding of it,
I say unconditionally, from the fact, that some
may join, provided that we adopt the proposed
amendments to the constitution: If 2000 members are
represented by the Eastern congregations they will be

adopted, as we have pledged ourselves to do so
we have one congregation in Phila, the Beth-Israel
report 70 "contributing members," now you can accertain
from Mr Lewine on what they base there report on
and let your congregation act accordingly.

I think that I have covered all the grounds
in the case, with the enclosed you will also
find the list of congregations and the number
of contributing members each report.

Since writing, I have accertained the status
on which our congregations will base their
contributing membership upon: and although I said
that if the constitution is amended that the
number would be augmented from 180 to 220 &c
I was wrong, as the fact is what is called
seat holders or renters here, in contradistinction
from contributing members, is, that they have
no privilege or immunities of the congrega-
tions whatever, except occupying a seat at
worship: only elected members have rights to bu-
rial or the services of the officers of the congre-
gation for mariages &c they can claim no rights,
but still if Dr Wise or Lilienthal is called upon
they marry any one whether a member or
not as the Parnassim exercise no control in
this matter""and the congregations extend favours also.
I hope you will comprehend fully what

I have written, I was not before aware,
until I consulted Mr Solomon Levi what the
status of our seat renters were, probably
differing somewhat those of Eastern Congre
gations. Still I think that I am safe
in saying that nine tenths fully of the
congregations now in the union, only report
their bona fide elected members, whilst
their seat renters have all rights and
immunities except voting at meetings &c.
Still we will never go back of their returns,
with kind regards, and hoping that the K. K.
Mickvah Isreal may fall next in line I
remain

I telegraphed you thus a written [?] by
Mr Lipman Levy secy of the union

"Under present constitution contributing
members only pay proposed contribution contrib-
uting members and seat holders must pay"
